organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

title.gco:CharacterString: 1:1,000,000-Scale Major Roads of the United States, 2012

otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: These data were downloaded from the National Atlas website (http://www.nationalatlas.gov/atlasftp.html) in August 2014.

collectiveTitle.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States of America, 1997-2014

abstract.gco:CharacterString: This map layer portrays the major roads in the United States, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. The file was produced by joining the individual State roads layers from the National Highway Planning Network (NHPN), Geographic Data Technology (GDT) Dynamap, and TIGER/Line files. This layer is part of the 1997-2014 edition of the National Atlas of the United States.

purpose.gco:CharacterString: These data are intended for geographic display and analysis at the national level, and for large regional areas. The data should be displayed and analyzed at scales appropriate for 1:1,000,000-scale data. No responsibility is assumed by the National Atlas of the United States in the use of these data.

credit.gco:CharacterString: U.S. Geological Survey. (2012). 1:1,000,000-Scale Major Roads of the United States, 2012. USGS. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/qh906sx2671.

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

contactInstructions.gco:CharacterString: For questions about this map layer or metadata, please contact the National Atlas using the information above, or through the U.S. Geological Survey contact page at http://www.usgs.gov/ask/. For distribution questions, please see the Distribution Information elsewhere in this metadata.

useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the U.S. Geological Survey regarding the utility of the data on any other system, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. No responsibility is assumed by the U.S. Geological Survey in the use of these data.

title.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States of America, 1997-2014

environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.3.1.4959

title.gco:CharacterString: Feature catalog for 1:1,000,000-Scale Major Roads of the United States, 2012

evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: The map layer was checked for topological consistency using ArcGIS. No other checks for logical consistency were performed on this map layer.

measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: The map layer was checked for topological consistency using ArcGIS. No other checks for logical consistency were performed on this map layer.
This map layer includes roads for all 50 States, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

description.gco:CharacterString: Roads consisting of Interstates, U.S. routes, and State routes were collected from NHPN and GDT Dynamap. In areas with a sparse road network, some roads deemed major were collected from NHPN. Roads for Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands were collected from 2006 2nd Edition TIGER/Line files.

All the 1:1,000,000-scale map layers were checked for vertical integration. Line positions were adjusted as necessary to remove overlaps. Wherever possible, linear features were separated by 300 meters, but were kept within 500 meters of their true location.

The data were converted to an Albers Equal Area projection. Attribute fields for miles and kilometers were added, and the values were calculated using ArcGIS. The data were then converted back to geographic coordinates. Adjustments were made to the roads attribution to clarify descriptive information and to correct errors.
The map layer was saved in shapefile and in file geodatabase formats.

Where road segments less than 0.1 KM in length were adjacent to longer segments with the same attributes, the segments were joined. All remaining roads less than 0.1 KM in length were evaluated and were either joined to neighboring segments, or their length was adjusted to greater than 0.1 KM. The data were converted to an Albers Equal Area projection, values for miles and kilometers were calculated using ArcGIS, and the data were converted back to geographic coordinates. There were several roads that needed a directional prefix added; the prefixes were obtained from the TIGER and NTAD sources.

Data along the Canadian border were adjusted so that the Canadian and USA 1:1,000,000-scale data sets can be used together as seamlessly as possible. Problem areas were identified by Natural Resources Canada (NRCan) and edits to the USA data were performed by the USGS. To identify problems, the National Atlas 1M roads 2012 data set was projected to the NRCan working coordinate system, which is a Lambert Conformal Conic projection with standard parallels of 49 and 77 degrees, datum of NAD83, an XY tolerance of 0.001 meters, and an XY resolution of 0.0001 meters. The Canadian and US data sets were displayed together and features were compared across the border. An initial set of comments and suggestions for edits were sent to the USGS by NRCan. NRCan used satellite imagery for reference during the editing process by converting the appropriate National Atlas 1:1,000,000-scale map layers and the 250K Canadian topo data to KML and loading the KMLs into GoogleEarth. Using the cursor coordinates in the ArcMap status bar, NRCan visually navigated and correlated the ArcMap and GoogleEarth vectors. NRCan exported their findings and sent them to the USGS for correction and (or) further comment. USGS reviewed the Canadian findings and returned the data to NRCan with comments. The U.S. data were either edited, not edited and further explanation was requested, or not edited and changes were suggested to for the Canadian data. This process was repeated until both NRCan and USGS felt that the data were satisfactorily harmonized.
Roads along the Mexican border were aligned based on reference to ESRI Basemaps, Google Maps, and Bing Maps.

Roads in the Virgin Islands that were previously identified as State routes were reattributed as VI routes. Because there is a separate Ferries data set available from the National Atlas, ferries were deleted from this data set.

otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: Numerous sources were used to perform quality-control and vertical integration, including all the 1:1,000,000-scale National Atlas map layers, a variety of online sources, and online USGS topographic maps. More information is available from the National Atlas contacts listed elsewhere in this metadata.
